questions.text: Which of the following statements are true?

choices.label: A
choices.text: A File object encapsulates the properties of a file or a path, but does not contain the methods for reading/writing.

choices.label: B
choices.text: You can use the PrintWriter class for outputting text to a file.

choices.label: C
choices.text: You can use the Scanner class for reading text from a file.

choices.label: D
choices.text: An input object is also called an input stream.

choices.label: E
choices.text: An output object is also called an output stream.

questions.text: Which of the following statements are true?

choices.label: A
choices.text: Text I/O is built upon binary I/O to provide a level of abstraction for character encoding and decoding.

choices.label: B
choices.text: Text I/O involves encoding and decoding.

choices.label: C
choices.text: Binary I/O does not require conversions.

choices.label: D
choices.text: Binary I/O is more efficient than text I/O, because binary I/O does not require encoding and decoding.

choices.label: E
choices.text: Binary files are independent of the encoding scheme on the host machine and thus are portable.

Which of the following statements is false?

choices.label: A
choices.text: All methods in FileInputStream/FileOutputStream are inherited from InputStream/OutputStream.

choices.label: B
choices.text: You can create a FileInputStream/FileOutputStream from a File object or a file name using FileInputStream/FileOutputStream constructors.

choices.label: C
choices.text: The return value -1 from the read() method signifies the end of file.

choices.label: D

choices.label: E

questions.text: To append data to an existing file, use _____________ to construct a FileOutputStream for file out.dat.

What does the following code do?

FileInputStream fis = new FileInputStream("test.dat");

choices.label: A
choices.text: It creates a new file named test.dat if it does not exist and opens the file so you can write to it.

choices.label: B
choices.text: It creates a new file named test.dat if it does not exist and opens the file so you can write to it and read from it.

choices.label: C
choices.text: It creates a new file named test.dat regardless of whether it exists or not and opens the file so you can write to it.

choices.label: D
choices.text: It creates a new file named test.dat regardless of whether it exists or not and opens the file so you can write to it and read from it.

choices.label: E
choices.text: It creates a FileInputStream for test.dat if test.dat exists.

Which of the following statements is correct to create a DataOutputStream to write to a file named out.dat?

After the following program is finished, how many bytes are written to the file t.dat?

import java.io.*;

public class Test {
  public static void main(String[] args) throws IOException {
    DataOutputStream output = new DataOutputStream(
      new FileOutputStream("t.dat"));
    output.writeShort(1234);
    output.writeShort(5678);
    output.close();
  }
}

After the following program is finished, how many bytes are written to the file t.dat?

import java.io.*;

public class Test {
  public static void main(String[] args) throws IOException {
    DataOutputStream output = new DataOutputStream(
      new BufferedOutputStream(FileOutputStream("t.dat")));
    output.writeChar('A');
    output.close();
  }
}

After the following program is finished, how many bytes are written to the file t.dat?

import java.io.*;

public class Test {

Which of the following statements are true? Please select all that apply.

choices.label: A
choices.text: All files are stored in binary format. So, all files are essentially binary files.

choices.label: B
choices.text: Text I/O is built upon binary I/O to provide a level of abstraction for character encoding and decoding.

choices.label: C
choices.text: Encoding and decoding are automatically performed by text I/O.

choices.label: D
choices.text: For binary input, you need to know exactly how data were written in order to read them in correct type and order.

questions.text: Which of the following statements are true? Please select all that apply.

choices.label: A
choices.text: ObjectInputStream/ObjectOutputStream enables you to perform I/O for objects in addition for primitive type values and strings.

choices.label: B
choices.text: Since ObjectInputStream/ObjectOutputStream contains all the functions of DataInputStream/DataOutputStream, you can replace DataInputStream/DataOutputStream completely by ObjectInputStream/ObjectOutputStream.

choices.label: C
choices.text: To write an object x on ObjectOutputStream output, invoke output.writeObject(x).

choices.label: D
choices.text: To read an object on ObjectInputStream input, invoke input.readObject().

questions.text:
The Loan class given in the text does not implement java.io.Serializable. Analyze the following code.

public class Foo implements java.io.Serializable {  
  private int v1;
  private static double v2;
  private Loan v3 = new Loan();
}

choices.label: A
choices.text: An instance of Foo can be serialized because Foo implements Serializable.

choices.label: B
choices.text: An instance of Foo cannot be serialized because Foo contains a non-serializable instance variable v3.

choices.label: C
choices.text: If you mark v3 as transient, an instance of Foo is serializable.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true?

choices.label: A
choices.text: A static variable is not serialized.

choices.label: B
choices.text: A transient variable is not serialized.

choices.label: C
choices.text: An object must be an instance of Serializable for it to be serialized.

choices.label: D
choices.text: The methods in an object are serialized.

Which of the following is the legal mode for creating a new RandomAccessFile stream?

What happens if the file test.dat does not exist when you attempt to compile and run the following code?

import java.io.*;

class Test  {
  public static void main(String[] args) {
    try {
      RandomAccessFile raf =
        new RandomAccessFile("test.dat", "r");
      int i = raf.readInt();
    }
    catch(IOException ex) {
      System.out.println("IO exception");
    }
  }
}

choices.label: A
choices.text: The program does not compile because raf is not created correctly.

choices.label: B
choices.text: The program does not compile because readInt() is not implemented in RandomAccessFile.

choices.label: C
choices.text: The program compiles, but throws an IOException because the file test.dat doesn't exist. The program displays IO exception.

choices.label: D
choices.text: The program compiles and runs fine, but nothing is displayed on the console.
